qas.question: How many Somerset soldiers were killed in WW1

answers.text: Many Somerset soldiers died during the First World War, with the Somerset Light Infantry suffering nearly 5,000 casualties

qas.question: How many counties had no casualties in WW1

answers.text: only nine, described as the Thankful Villages, had none of their residents killed

qas.question: The county was base for what in WW2

answers.text: for troops preparing for the D-Day landings

qas.question: What is the Tauton stop line

answers.text: The Taunton Stop Line was set up to repel a potential German invasion

qas.question: What was one of the Thankful Villages?
Which village suffered the most First World War casualties?
How many Somerset soldiers died in all in the First World War?
How many Somerset soldiers did in the Second World War?
How many pill boxes can still be seen along the coast?

context: <a0_0>Many Somerset soldiers died during the First World War, with the Somerset Light Infantry suffering nearly <b6_0><b7_0>5,000<b7_0/><b6_0/> casualties<a0_0/>. War memorials were put up in most of the county's towns and villages; <a1_0>only <b8_0>nine<b8_0/>, described as the Thankful Villages, had none of their residents killed<a1_0/>. During the Second World War the county was a base <a2_0>for troops preparing for the D-Day landings<a2_0/>. Some of the hospitals which were built for the casualties of the war remain in use. <a3_0>The <b4_0>Taunton<b4_0/> Stop Line was set up to repel a potential German invasion<a3_0/>. The remains of its pill boxes can still be seen along the coast, and south through <b5_0>Ilminster<b5_0/> and Chard.
